Title:
Extensive gene flow over Europe and possible speciation over
Eurasia in the ectomycorrhizal basidiomycete Laccaria amethystina
complex
Keywords:
Cryptic speciation, Ectomycorrhiza, Gene flow, Inbreeding,
Isolation by distance, Ring species, Phylogeography, Population
structure, Microsatellite markers
Abstract:
Biogeographic patterns and large-scale genetic structure
have been little studied in ectomycorrhizal 32 fungi, despite the
ecological and economic importance of ectomycorrhizal symbioses. We
coupled 33 population genetics and phylogenetic approaches to understand
spatial structure in fungal 34 populations on a continental scale. Using
9 microsatellite markers, we characterised gene flow 35 among 16
populations of the widespread ectomycorrhizal basidiomycete Laccaria
amethystina over 36 Europe (i.e. over 2900km). We also widened our scope
to two additional populations from Japan 37 (104 km away), and compared
them with European populations through microsatellite markers and 38
multi-locus phylogenies, using 3 nuclear genes (NAR, G6PD and ribosomal
DNA) and two 39 mitochondrial ribosomal genes. European L. amethystina
populations displayed limited differentiation (average FST40 =0.041) and
very weak isolation by distance. This panmictic European 41 pattern may
result from effective aerial dispersal of spores, high genetic diversity
in populations, and 42 mutualistic interactions with multiple hosts that
all facilitate migration. The multi-locus phylogeny 43 based on nuclear
genes confirmed that Japanese and European specimens were closely
related but 44 clustered on a geographical basis. By using
microsatellite markers, we found that Japanese populations were strongly
differentiated from the European populations (FST45 =0.416), more than
46 expected by extrapolating the European pattern of isolation by
distance. Population structure 47 analyses clearly separated the
populations into two clusters, i.e. European and Japanese clusters. We
48 discuss the possibility of isolation by distance in a continuous
population (considering some 49 evidence for a ring species over the
Northern Hemisphere) versus an allopatric speciation over 50 Eurasia,
making L. amethystina a promising model of intercontinental species for
future studies.
